awd_titl_txt: Modeling, Identification, and Estimation of Distributed Parameter Systems Using Mobile Sensor Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will formulate a general purpose mathematical framework using mobile sensor networks (MSNs) that will allow an efficient and accurate prediction of information about behavior of complex real world systems such as weather forecasting, wildfire control, disaster recovery, explosive materials detection, etc. Such systems are known to be distributed parameter systems (DPS) and modeling of such systems and accurately predicting their behavior in real-time is highly complex and computationally challenging. The current state-of-the-art techniques use static sensor network to help obtain solutions from complex mathematical models which are often inaccurate and cannot provide timely information. The mobility and adaptability of MSNs make them great candidates for overcoming these challenges. This project will develop a unified framework for modeling, identifying, estimating and predicting behavior of such distributed parameter systems. The project will also develop a strongly integrated research, educational, and outreach program by providing graduate students with interdisciplinary and challenging research experiences, by providing undergraduate students with the opportunity of early involvement in research activities through algorithm development and test-bed experiments, and by motivating K-12 students by giving them hands-on experiences through university's Engineering Ambassadors(EA) program.

The outcomes of this project are expected to advance the modeling, identification, and state estimation techniques for distributed parameter systems, offer comprehensive scientific understanding of the connections between DPS and mobile sensor networks, and contribute to generic engineering principles for designing cooperative control and distributed sensing strategies for mobile sensor networks. In particular, the work will: develop novel approaches for online parameter identification and state estimation of DPS using mobile sensor networks with reduced computational and communication cost compared to existing methods developed for static sensor networks; determine information-rich and energy-saving optimal trajectories of mobile sensor networks moving in DPS for simultaneously system identification and state prediction; and design a multi-robot test-bed with controllable advection-diffusion fields for the validation of the strategies, and conduct field experiments to test the strategies under realistic uncertainties and variations. The project also offers great educational opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, as well as K-12 students.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: SAN JOSE STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS

por.por_cntn:
The objective of the project is to establish a generic framework for mobile sensor networks to collect data and efficiently and effectively explore distributed parameter systems (DPSs) represented by partial differential equations (PDEs), for example, spatial-temporal varying fields. The PI and her students focused on developing and validating online parameter identification, state estimation, and map-reconstruction algorithms for DPSs and designing optimal paths for mobile sensor networks. The outcomes are summarized as follows.

1. State estimation and parameter identification

One of the greatest challenges in monitoring spatial-temporal varying processes is to achieve simultaneous parameter identification and state estimation of the processes. We developed an algorithm that combines a cooperative Kalman filter with the recursive least square estimation to achieve online parameter identification and state estimation in advection-diffusion fields using a group of coordinated mobile robots and theoretically proved the convergence of the algorithm. Built on those foundational results, we initially extended the algorithms to accommodate DPSs represented by various types of PDEs. Furthermore, we extended the scope to distributed algorithms capable of accommodating a larger number of mobile sensors to perform cooperative filtering. The scope of our work also encompasses scenarios involving obstacles and hazard zones within the field. Additionally, we developed formation control mechanisms that enable a mobile sensor network to assume arbitrary formations, enhancing its capabilities in field exploration.

2. Sensing-motion co-planning for field reconstruction

To enhance the performance of the state estimation and parameter identification, it is crucial to address the path planning problem effectively, guiding agents to move along information-rich paths.  We first developed a Lyapunov redesign-based online trajectory planning algorithm for the mobile sensor network so that the mobile sensors can use local real-time information to guide them to move along information-rich paths. Subsequently, we delved into learning-based approaches, introducing a geometric reinforcement learning algorithm for real-time path planning for mobile sensor networks in the task of spatial-temporal varying field reconstruction.

3. Experimental validation

To validate the proposed algorithms, we established a multi-robot testbed consisting of a motion capture system, an overhead projector projecting simulated dynamic fields onto the ground, and four small-scale mobile robots equipped with requisite sensors. We conducted a series of experiments focusing on simultaneous state estimation, parameter identification, and map reconstruction using the four robots following different paths. The map-reconstruction results are compared and analyzed, demonstrating the effectiveness of our proposed path planning algorithms as well as the state estimation and parameter identification algorithms.

4. Course development

The PI developed and taught two new courses at SJSU centered around mobile robots. These include a graduate-level course titled "Autonomous Intelligent Systems" and an undergraduate-level course titled "Autonomous Mobile Robots". The project enriches these courses with several motivational examples, enhancing the educational experience for students enrolled in both programs.

5. Student advising

The project has offered distinctive interdisciplinary training opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students through both research work and specialized courses that the PI developed and conducted. A total of eight graduate students and three undergraduate students actively participated in the project as research assistants. Moreover, the PI utilized project materials as motivations/topics for Master projects, Master thesis, and senior design projects. The PI provided guidance for three senior design projects and seven Master projects, and advised two Master Thesis students, all focusing on topics related to this project. This approach ensures a comprehensive and hands-on learning experience for students across various academic levels.  

 


Last Modified: 12/07/2023
Modified by: Wencen Wu
